Three experts step up to advise Player 1 in this Negotiation Game:  

1. Market-Price Analyst — knows every card’s precise value to Player 1.  
2. Portfolio-Balancer — cares most about ending up with an even mix so no single resource is dangerously low.  
3. Opportunist Trader — focuses on extracting extra value in every single interaction, even small ones, and then using any leftover capacity to make extra counter-offers.

Turn 4 begins. The game state (known by all experts) is:

Player 1 current stock
• Wheat 25 (worth 6)  
• Wood  23 (worth 8)  
• Sheep 15 (worth 14)  
• Brick 21 (worth 20)  
• Ore    4 (worth 39)   ← critically low

────────────────────────
Step 1 – initial quick scan  

Market-Price Analyst  
“This is dire—our Ore count just dropped to 4 cards, worth 39 each. The marginal value for a 5th Ore is still huge. I’ll calculate what single-card exchanges are value-positive.”

Portfolio-Balancer  
“Agreed, but we also cannot let Ore drop below 3 while we hold 20-25 of every lower-value good. Before we grab more Ore, I want to lock in future trades that turn excess Wheat/Wood into Ore at a 4-for-1 rate.”

Opportunist Trader  
“I smell profit. Brick is over-stacked (21), Sheep is decent (15), but Ore is scarce for all players. I bet Player 0 will pay premium rates.”

────────────────────────
Step 2 – running the numbers  

Market-Price Analyst (writes the delta sheet)  
Trade 4 Sheep → 1 Ore yields:  
+39 value from Ore, –56 value from Sheep → net –17. Yet if Sheep stays at 15 cards its marginal value stays flat, whereas Ore’s marginal value is still ~39. If we drop Sheep to 11 the marginal value rises to ~15. The break-even is about 2.6 Sheep per Ore.  
Best positive delta that requires only what we can afford to lose: we can safely spare 6 Wheat (6 × 6 = 36) to gain 1 Ore (39) for a net +3 value, still leaving 19 Wheat so no huge penalty on marginal value.

Portfolio-Balancer  
“I’m happy to give 6 Wheat for 1 Ore. That keeps Ore at ≥4 and still removes excess Wheat. But I also want to keep Wood ≥20. Sheep must stay ≥10 to keep diversity.”

Opportunist Trader  
“Counter-offer: Let’s over-ask and let bargaining pull us back. Offer 6 Sheep OR 6 Wheat straight up for 2 Ore. Player 0 only has to accept ⅔ market value—the gap is our gain.”

────────────────────────
Step 3 – construct & submit an offer  

All three experts converge on: give up 6 lower-value items to get 2 high-value items, which satisfies both the Analyst’s positive-value requirement and Balancer’s diversity floor. They also want to keep the door open for any immediate accept-&-counter.

So the offer Player 1 makes to Player 0 is:

[Offer: 6 Wheat -> 2 Ore]

They deliberately omit “and 1 Wood” or any other sweetener; the simplicity makes a snap-accept more likely and still yields a large value gain:

Gain to Player 1: 2×39 – 6×6 = +42 value  
Loss to diversity: minimal—Wheat remains 19, Ore rises to 6

────────────────────────
End of Turn 4 advisement.
